I don't trust this thing because you never know exactly what you get! Why not just customizing a copy of Windows XP Pro by yourself? That way, at least, you will know for sure what is included in it.

Well, if you want a fully customized unattended copy of XP Pro, all you really need is A) the different components that you want to integrate into the image file (like the image file of Windows XP Pro, the Service Pack, the plugins, codecs, programs, etc.). B) A tool called "nLite" (http://www.nliteos.com/ - requires at least .NET Framework 2.0) which you use in order to customize/pre-configure/build the entire image with. C) Finally, just burn the image file you created with "nLite" with a burning application of your choice! I recommend "Alcohol 120%" because it is by far more reliable and less bloated than Nero and Roxio (totally useless). 

This way, you will certainly know what you get. And what the heck, you can even pre-configure the whole thing to have the product key integrated in it, so you don't have to type in the product key each time you install it on a machine. Very simple and efficient! :) 
You might wanna check the image by mounting it on a virtual drive (using tools like "Alcohol 120%" or "Deamon Tools") prior to burning it to see whether it works or not. Or, just installing it on a virtual PC. It's not as hard as it sounds and best of all: you get exactly what you ask for.

This file is a waist of time to download. Took a lot of time to fancy up the background on the install process but come on. What the hell is up with all the software????!! Seriously. You could have got the size down to at least 550MB if you would have threw out all that crap you put in there. 

Don't worry guys, I will upload Windows XP Pro with a working key for everyone. Since some people around here can't grasp the concept of simple.

@zsi52: 

Just for your information...Nero is a piece-of-shit, unreliable, unstable, bloated, resource-hungry, and buggy crapware! Especially the latest version of it. The reason why I'm pointing this out is the fact that it has miserable failed me numerious times. If you are dealing with image files (like iso, img, gem, msd, bin, nrg, you name it!), I would highly recommend "Alcohol 120%" (shareware). It is very powerful and efficient..and best of all reliable.

@tika-mika: Officially, Microsoft has switched their official Service Pack 2 download links to their Windows Update site, presumably due to piracy. HOWEVER, I managed to find two different links, pointing to Service Pack 2 for "Windows XP Professional": 

English Version: http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/thankyou.aspx?familyId=049C9DBE-3B8E-4F30-8245-9E368D3CDB5A&displayLang=en

Swedish Version (Since I assume that this is the one you were looking for): http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?displaylang=sv&FamilyID=049C9DBE-3B8E-4F30-8245-9E368D3CDB5A

Good luck! PM me for further questions. Cheers! :)

@tika-mika: Oops, I messed up on the first link (English Version) that I posted previously. The appropriate URL to that one should be: http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=049C9DBE-3B8E-4F30-8245-9E368D3CDB5A&displaylang=en

"rimad_ at 2006-12-16 01:53 GMT:

Just installed it, works fine, didnt ask me for key or anything but it has bunch of programs i don't want but well, hitting uninstall isn't that hard. I think you guys need fresh installation, you are "updating" your system or something thats why it asks for key."

@rimad_:
Well, of course it is easy to install an unattended copy of Windows XP like this one. At least, for those who have done it before. But the question is: Is it really worth with all the programs? Sure it is "easy" to uninstall softwares by using the built-in "Add/Remove Programs" feature from the Control Panel. But, what many people fail to realize is the fact that all softwares leave things behind (like registry keys/entries, files/folders) Well, unless if you have a hell of a good uninstallation strategy and the right tools/knowledge to perform a clean uninstallation, the problem will be solved. But, still I think it's stupid to have to uninstall something that you intentionally installed and didn't even need in the first place, as others here have pointed out indirectly. I'm not trying to be rude. It's just that I'm telling you guys what I believe is right from my own experiences. Furthermore, there is absolutely no offence aimed at "newm0nk" for doing is job of sharing his work with us, so he deserves to be credited for helping the torrent community to breathe, unlike those ass wads out there who cheat, spam or spread viruses and other sorts of malwares.
Finally, thanks "Little Fingers" for noticing. I had no idea of how beneficial the Student version of this OS is. Cheers! :)

A number of people have referred to the Student Version which I think is ideal with its volume key.Having said that I recently put in a larger hard drive 200gg tobe precise but onfortunately the Student Version will as I have discovered from other colleagues will only recognise 120gg or less and to install it on a bigger hard drive needs a partition creating.
However if the Student Version had SP2 integrated that problem would be overcome.So anything which is bootable and has SP2 BUILT IN HAS TO BE WELCOMED.
